text: morning chaps, just a general question on staking for those that use kelly style staking, but in the scenario where you have one bet that settle in like 1 hour lets say, then a second new bet comes along which settles in a few minutes, what % of bankroll are you basing the second bet on? Are you basing the bet on the bankroll what you have available at the time of bet or do you attribute some value to the initial bet?

elements.text: morning chaps, just a general question on staking for those that use kelly style staking, but in the scenario where you have one bet that settle in like 1 hour lets say, then a second new bet comes along which settles in a few minutes, what % of bankroll are you basing the second bet on? Are you basing the bet on the bankroll what you have available at the time of bet or do you attribute some value to the initial bet?

text: Clearly paying what they pay, I assume staff turnover is going to be fairly high. How does IP get controlled in such situations? Mono repo’s out of the question and keep everything very siloed / locked down?

elements.text: Clearly paying what they pay, I assume staff turnover is going to be fairly high. How does IP get controlled in such situations? Mono repo’s out of the question and keep everything very siloed / locked down?

text: Are the bets independent?

elements.text: Are the bets independent?

text: yes

elements.text: yes

text:
I will just make a heuristic argument (although there is an exact answer and I need to look up the paper)
Typically in real world situations the kelly size bet is usually a small fraction (i.e one third or half kelly) as is the edge for any given bet. Considering the bets are independent, I would just bet with same bank roll assumption

elements.text:
I will just make a heuristic argument (although there is an exact answer and I need to look up the paper)

text: and in the case where you make 50 bets at the same time lets say?

text: hmmm, maybe look up multi period mean variance optimization papers. <https://opus4.kobv.de/opus4-zib/files/418/SC-99-30.pdf>

elements.text: hmmm, maybe look up multi period mean variance optimization papers.

text: re 50 bets, if bets are independent and your mean edge and variance computations are reasonable I’d still treat bank roll as the same. on expectation your bankroll grows proportionally to mean edge.

elements.text: re 50 bets, if bets are independent and your mean edge and variance computations are reasonable I’d still treat bank roll as the same. on expectation your bankroll grows proportionally to mean edge.

text: ofcourse if your edge computation is busted then this heuristic does not work either

elements.text: ofcourse if your edge computation is busted then this heuristic does not work either

text: If you truly want to avoid heuristics then my suggestion is to look at markowitz multi period mean variance optimization (this is the generalisation of kelly to multiple bet scenarios with no assumptions of independence either)

elements.text: If you truly want to avoid heuristics then my suggestion is to look at markowitz multi period mean variance optimization (this is the generalisation of kelly to multiple bet scenarios with no assumptions of independence either)

text: I just scale according to maximum expected liability (worked out through analysis of past betting and the corresponding size multiplier at the time)

text: Kelly is just maximising the geometric growth rate or equivalently expected log return. You can fairly easily calculate the expected log return by integrating over all possibilities for simultaneous bets or some existing unsettled bets plus new bets. Then maximise using your favourite optimiser (although you can work it out analytically as well)

elements.text: Kelly is just maximising the geometric growth rate or equivalently expected log return. You can fairly easily calculate the expected log return by integrating over all possibilities for simultaneous bets or some existing unsettled bets plus new bets. Then maximise using your favourite optimiser (although you can work it out analytically as well)

text: The way I do it for in-play tennis where I can bet on any point on any match (and there can be up to 20 matches in play at any one time) is that every bet is treated independently, and from past analysis I can work out roughly how often I bet on average. So I have a staking plan per bet which is scaled to give me a rough turnover

So I have a staking plan per bet which is scaled to give me a rough turnover

text: The issue is not with that line per se, the issue is `df` is a slice of a DataFrame not a DataFrame itself

text:
The suggestion is saying that rather than do
```df = df[some_logical_condition]
df['sys_time'] = datetime.utcnow().strftime("%d/%m/%Y %I:%M:%S.%f")```
You should do
```df.loc[some_logical_condition,'sys_time'] = datetime.utcnow().strftime("%d/%m/%Y %I:%M:%S.%f")```

elements.text: The suggestion is saying that rather than do

df = df[some_logical_condition]
df['sys_time'] = datetime.utcnow().strftime("%d/%m/%Y %I:%M:%S.%f")
You should do
df.loc[some_logical_condition,'sys_time'] = datetime.utcnow().strftime("%d/%m/%Y %I:%M:%S.%f")

Another way to do it, again depending on what else your code is doing, would be to use the
.assign
method:
df = df[some_logical_condition].assign(sys_time=datetime.utcnow().strftime("%d/%m/%Y %I:%M:%S.%f"))
Generally, methods like this always return a
new
DataFrame. You can set multiple columns in one call:
df = df[some_logical_condition].assign(sys_time=datetime.utcnow().strftime("%d/%m/%Y %I:%M:%S.%f"), x=y)
You can also do a pipeline of methods, each returning a new DataFrame, e.g.
